instruction: Can the combination of single particle mass spectrometry (SPAMS) and a fluorescent aerosol particle sizer (FLAPS) be considered a superior spectroscopic method for the detection of microbiological aerosols, compared to traditional methods?
Output: Yes, the combination of single particle mass spectrometry (SPAMS) and a fluorescent aerosol particle sizer (FLAPS) can be considered a superior spectroscopic method for the detection of microbiological aerosols compared to traditional methods. This is because the merging of FLAPS and SPAMS technologies allows for the elimination of interference and inefficiency issues that are encountered with traditional methods. The FLAPS component can eliminate the majority of inorganic ambient aerosols, reducing the data volume for SPAMS. Additionally, SPAMS can eliminate the secondary fluorescence interference that plagues FLAPS. By combining these technologies, the detection of microbial aerosol signals can be done more precisely, especially with the addition of an enhanced machine learning classifier.
